p: In summary, Japanese institutional arrangements—bank financing, cross-shareholding, enterprise unions, and lifetime employment—aligned the interests of financial capital, production capital, and labor in a manner that allowed them to maintain the social conditions of innovation. Consequently, Japanese firms drove American competitors out of the electronics and PV markets. They also avoided the corporate upheaval that afflicted their American rivals—a restructuring that, to a large extent, was caused by Japanese competition in the first place.
